header.title: Wicca Advanced: A Second Year within the Craft

central_thesis: Wicca Advanced aims to provide students with a deep and meaningful Wiccan education, building upon basic frameworks. It explores various magical arts, emphasizing personal spiritual development, the operative side of magic, and the importance of service to others within a structured, year-long course. The Kabbalah is presented as a fundamental underpinning for Western magical practice, particularly for understanding correspondences and achieving spiritual union with the Divine.

structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces various divination methods such as Tarot, Palmistry, Skrying, Runes, Pendulums, Tea and Molten Wax, and the I Ching. It delves into the theoretical underpinnings of divination, including concepts like Akashic Records, Synchronicity, and Precognition, offering different viewpoints on how they function. Practical exercises for regression and preparatory invocations are included.

structure_content.chapter_title: Celebrating the Cycle of Human Life
structure_content.summary: This chapter focuses on Wiccan rites of passage for significant life stages: Wiccaning (child dedication), Handfasting (marriage), and Funeral Rites. It emphasizes adaptability of ceremonies, community involvement, and the underlying Wiccan philosophies on life and death, including reincarnation. Exercises include past life recollection and spellwork for happiness and success.

This chapter provides an introduction to herbs, detailing their astrological correspondences (Planets, Star Signs, Body Parts) and various herbal preparations (infusions, decoctions, poultices, lotions, inhalations, compresses, massage oils, baths). Several common herbs and their medicinal, magical, culinary, and aromatic uses are discussed. Practical exercises involve ritual baths, incense, circle casting, and herbal spellwork.

structure_content.chapter_title: Studying Further the Art of Magic
structure_content.summary: This chapter advances magical theory, exploring concepts like the Powers of the Sphinx ('To Know, To Will, To Dare, To Remain Silent'), Sex Magic (symbolic and actual versions), the Use of the Scourge, Talismans, Amulets, Evocation of Spirits (with safety warnings), and Magic of Contagion. It details the consecration of magical objects. Research projects focus on timing magic and planetary squares, with exercises on using various elemental and conceptual pentagrams.

This chapter introduces the Kabbalah as the foundational framework for Western magical practice. It explains the Tree of Life, its ten Sephiroth (emanations) and 22 paths, and the Four Kabbalistic Worlds (Atziluth, Briah, Yetzirah, Assiah), linking them to the Four Elements. The chapter demonstrates how Kabbalah organizes magical correspondences and its inextricable link to the Tarot system. Exercises are provided to help familiarization with the Tree of Life.

This chapter teaches techniques for exploring higher planes of existence. It details the Kabbalistic Pillar of Balance ritual (Golden Dawn and Wiccan adaptations) as a structured method for spiritual progression, mapping Sephiroth to parts of the human body. It also covers astral travel through simulacrum projection and meditative explorations of specific Sephiroth realms (Malkuth, Yesod, Tiphareth, Hod, Netzach). An exercise for relieving tension is included.

This chapter introduces the basics of Astrology, defining its core components: Planets (energies), Zodiac Signs (ways of directing energies), and Houses (areas of life). It provides detailed tables of planetary qualities, dignities, exaltations, and detriments, as well as Zodiac sign qualities and elemental divisions. The chapter begins the practical process of creating a natal chart, including steps for time conversion, finding sidereal time, Ascendant, and Midheaven.

Building on Part One, this chapter guides the reader through calculating the precise positions of planets at birth and determining their Aspects, providing tables for proportional logarithms and aspect definitions. It then explains how to integrate planets, signs, houses, triplicities, quadriplicities, and aspects for interpreting a natal chart. The chapter also covers the construction of planetary squares and sigils for talismanic magic.

This chapter focuses on developing psychic abilities, starting with enhancing the five physical senses as a prerequisite for 'extra sensory perception' (ESP). It explores different types of ESP: Post-cognition, Precognition, Clairvoyance, Telepathy, and Psychokinesis, discussing their mechanisms and evidence. Practical exercises are provided, including Zener card experiments and relaxation techniques. The chapter also addresses common sceptical challenges to psychic phenomena.

This chapter explores the use of crystals in Wiccan healing and magical practice. It discusses the influence of crystal colors on mood and body, their piezoelectric properties, and their connection to Chakras for balancing energy. Detailed tables provide Kabbalistic, elemental, zodiacal, and planetary correspondences for various crystals, guiding practitioners in selecting stones for specific effects. Research projects encourage collecting and experimenting with crystals.

This chapter examines Wiccan attitudes towards sex, emphasizing reverence, spirituality, and ethical consensual practice within stable relationships. It describes the Great Rite as a ritualized sexual act to raise power and work magic, allowing for a 'divine oblivion' state. Both symbolic and actual versions of the Great Rite are presented, with a discussion on how different coven structures or solitary practitioners might adapt the rite.

The concluding chapter guides students in reflecting on their completed 'Second Degree' level of Wiccan education, assessing its personal value, and considering future paths of study or service. It offers practical advice on designing a personal rite of passage to mark this achievement and provides comprehensive guidance on the practicalities and challenges of setting up and running a coven, emphasizing organization, creativity, and the principle of service to others.

key_concepts.definition: The power of foreseeing. Defined by Aleister Crowley as reducing to questions of 'Of what are things composed?' and 'How shall we combine them to our greater advantage?'. The Farrars describe it as 'clairvoyance using tools,' while the Ciceros call it 'the art of uncovering the divine meaning behind chance events.' Starhawk views it as focusing awareness and engaging heightened intuition for spiritual and psychological counseling. It allows for an overview of a situation to see future progression and offer analysis and advice.

A repository of all human experiences throughout past ages, similar to Carl Jung's 'collective unconscious.' It is believed to be a deep level of collective memories and patterns of behavior common to many mammals, linking humans at an unconscious level. Witches access these through meditative trance or intermediary spiritual guides.

Meaningful coincidences, as theorized by Jung. In divination, it suggests that patterns formed by divinatory tools (e.g., cards, stones) are not random but synchronicitous events with meaning and import, allowing the diviner to connect to the collective unconscious or Akashic records and interpret future progressions based on current events.

The ability to receive information about a future event or series of events without physical forewarning or deduction. The book discusses two scientific views of the future – a fixed existence (Einsteinian Physics) or an infinite range of possible futures (Copenhagen Interpretation of Quantum Theory) – both of which allow for precognitive experiences.

A divination method using an object (like a crystal ball or black mirror) as a focal point to empty the mind, induce a trance state, and connect with the Akashic records. This process can lead to visions appearing as milky clouds, lights, or images in the diviner's mind or directly in their consciousness.

Objects specially created or adapted for a specific magical purpose. They combine symbols from various esoteric sources (Astrology, Kabbalah, Numerology, etc.) into a 'magical formula' to aid in focusing the mind, fixing intentions, and influencing desired outcomes. Unlike general good luck charms, talismans are precisely constructed for specific magical workings.

A type of talisman specifically used for protection. Historically, they were used to protect against the 'Evil Eye,' putrefaction, or to aid the soul's journey in the Underworld. Modern Witches use amulets to guard against specific, defined threats or to embody a desire for the soul's safe journey in the Summerlands (afterlife).

An ancient Hebrew tradition of teachings, deriving from 'mouth to ear' or 'to receive,' that has significantly influenced Western magical practice. It provides a comprehensive philosophical and operative framework for seeing and understanding the order and relationship of all things, from the Divine to the mundane, primarily centered on the glyph of the Tree of Life.

The central glyph of the Unwritten Kabbalah, composed of ten spheres (Sephiroth) and 22 paths. The Sephiroth represent expressions of different types of energy or emanations, ranging from the Divine (Kether) to physical manifestation (Malkuth). The paths are channels for divine energy and routes for spiritual ascent, forming a universal frame for organizing knowledge and experiences in magic.

A Kabbalistic meditative exercise, adapted from the Golden Dawn's 'Middle Pillar Ritual,' designed for spiritual progression and balancing energies within the body. It involves visualizing brilliant white spheres of light at specific Sephiroth points (Kether, Daath, Tiphareth, Yesod, Malkuth) corresponding to different parts of the human body, while intoning divine names to connect with divine energy.

A ghostly double or 'doppelganger' made of astral energy. It is created by separating the astral body from the aura and projecting consciousness into it, enabling astral travel and exploration of the Astral Plane. The technique requires intense visualization, concentration, and practice to maintain its existence and move within it.

Abilities that allow experience or influence of the world through non-physical means, beyond the five conventional senses. This includes Post-cognition (knowing past events without physical cues), Precognition (knowing future events), Clairvoyance ('clear-seeing' of unseen/hidden things), Telepathy (mind-to-mind communication), and Psychokinesis (mind's influence on matter or events).

Energy centers within the human body, stemming from Hindu culture. Generally, seven chakras are recognized, aligned from the base of the spine to the crown of the head. Their role is to draw in universal life force energy (prana) to maintain spiritual, mental, emotional, and physical health, each associated with specific physiological functions, aspects of consciousness, and colors.

A ritualized sexual intercourse in Wicca, used to raise power and work magic. It is practiced by consenting adult partners, typically in private, and exists in both symbolic and actual versions. It is intended to revere the polarity between male and female energies (God and Goddess) and to achieve a state of 'divine oblivion' or nothingness, from which magical intentions can be released.

A summation of the four essential skills for magical working: 'To Know' (understanding oneself and one's True Path), 'To Will' (imagining, setting goals with 100% conviction and desire), 'To Dare' (having the courage to act and believe in one's ability to effect change), and 'To Remain Silent' (knowing when to speak and when not to, to preserve magical energy and avoid external interference).

Five-pointed stars used in magical practice. Elemental Pentagrams (Air, Earth, Fire, Water, Spirit) are invoked or banished by specific movements to work with different energetic qualities. Other conceptual pentagrams include the Iron Pentagram (meditation on Sex, Power, Pride, Passion, Self) and Pentagrams representing stages of life (Birth, Initiation, Consummation, Repose/Death, Spirit) for self-reflection and balance.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a comprehensive operative magical system that blends Wiccan philosophy with core tenets of Western Esotericism, primarily the Kabbalah. The system hinges on developing 'will' and 'imagination' through disciplined practice, with the Tree of Life serving as the primary map for organizing correspondences and understanding energetic flows from the Divine to the physical. Practitioners are guided through a holistic path of self-development, utilizing various tools and rituals for divination, energy manipulation, healing, and exploring higher planes of existence, always emphasizing ethical practice and service to others.
rituals: Elemental Pentagrams (Invoking/Banishing Air, Earth, Fire, Water, Spirit)
Pillar of Balance Ritual (Golden Dawn & Wiccan adaptations)
Meditations on Sephiroth (Malkuth, Yesod, Tiphareth, Hod, Netzach)
Developing ESP Skills (Clairvoyance, Telepathy using Zener cards)
The Great Rite (Symbolic and Actual versions)

relevant_quotes.text: Divination…is the most sensitive, difficult and perilous branch of Magick.
The abuse of divination has been responsible, more than any other cause, for the discredit into which the whole subject of Magick had fallen.
The angel that presided over my birth Said “Little creature, form’d of Joy & Mirth, Go love without the help of any Thing on Earth.”

I know a bank whereon the wild thyme blows, Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows Quite over-canopied with luscious woodbine, With sweet musk-roses, and with eglantine: There sleeps Titania some time of the night, Lull’d in these flowers with dances and delight.
Every intentional act is a magickal act.
As the athame is to the male, so the cup is to the female; and conjoined, they bring blessedness.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book serves as a crucial, in-depth guide for intermediate Wiccan practitioners, particularly solitaries, by offering a structured 'second year' curriculum. It uniquely integrates diverse Western esoteric traditions, such as Kabbalah and Golden Dawn magic, directly into Wiccan practice. The explicit connection of Wiccan rituals and magic to Kabbalistic principles provides a robust theoretical foundation often lacking in introductory texts. Its emphasis on self-practice, detailed exercises, and systematic record-keeping makes it highly practical for individual magical and spiritual progression. The author also actively addresses the quality of online magical education, asserting the validity and depth of this course's training.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of intermediate Wiccan students who have completed foundational Wiccan courses or possess a solid understanding of basic Wiccan principles and magic. It is especially well-suited for solitary practitioners seeking a structured, in-depth path for advanced study and practical application of complex magical and esoteric concepts, without requiring coven membership or direct teacher supervision. Individuals interested in the philosophical and operative synthesis of Wicca with traditions like the Kabbalah and Golden Dawn will also find this book highly relevant.
